newsitem.title: FRANCE: Analyst cuts EU grain sowing forecast to 38 mln ha.
newsitem.headline: Analyst cuts EU grain sowing forecast to 38 mln ha.

text.p: French grain analyst Strategie Grains said on Monday it had cut its estimate for European Union grain sowings for the 1997 harvest by 100,000 hectares to 38 million hectares.
This would still represent a rise of three percent over 1996 sowings of 36.8 million hectares, it said.
Last month Strategie Grains said 1997 grain sowings would reach 38.1 million hectares.

Strategie Grains also predicted 1997 grain production within the European Union might rise by one percent to 206.5 million tonnes compared with 207.4 million tonnes forecast in February and a revised 204.2 million tonnes produced in 1996.
The analyst said that despite a lower set-aside rate, a strong rise in rapeseed and protein seeds sowings limited the rise in area sown to grain.
In its monthly report for March, the analyst warned that production estimates remained subject to adjustment.
Yield forecasts were based on a trend and would be fine-tuned in coming months in line with weather conditons.
The latest forecast assumed 1997/98 grain yields would decline two percent to 5.4 tonnes per hectare from 5.5 tonnes in the previous campaign.
Strategie Grains held its estimate for 1997/98 soft wheat output at 93.1 million tonnes. This would represent a rise of three percent over the 90.8 million tonnes produced in 1996/97.
Wheat sowings would rise by three percent to 14.2 million hectares and yields remain steady at 6.6 tonnes per hectare.
The analyst now targets barley production at 52.3 million tonnes against a previous forecast of 52.4 million tonnes and 52.5 million tonnes produced in 1996/97.
Barley sowings would rise by four percent to 11.8 million hectares and yields decline four percent to 4.4 tonnes per hectare.

Strategie Grains now puts EU maize output at 35.3 milion tonnes against 36 million tonnes forecast in February. This would represent a rise of three percent over 34.2 million tonnes produced previously.
Maize sowings would rise by five percent to 4.3 million hectare and yield decline one percent to 8.2 tonnes per hectare.
